solution_line_template: Brian requires a total of ${subway_fare_one_way} + ${subway_fare_one_way} = $<<{subway_fare_one_way}+{subway_fare_one_way}={subway_fare_total}>>{subway_fare_total} to pay for the round trip subway fare
We also know he has spent half (1/2) the amount he spent on kiwis on bananas, so he'll spend (1/2) * ${kiwi_spent} = ${banana_spent} on bananas

So far in total he has spent ${subway_fare_total} for his subway fare + ${banana_spent} on bananas + ${kiwi_spent} on kiwis = ${subway_fare_total} + ${banana_spent} + ${kiwi_spent} = $<<{subway_fare_total}+{banana_spent}+{kiwi_spent}={total_spent_so_far}>>{total_spent_so_far}

If he left his house with only ${initial_money}, then all he will have left for apples would be ${initial_money} - ${total_spent_so_far} = $<<{initial_money}-{total_spent_so_far}={money_left_for_apples}>>{money_left_for_apples}
If a bag of apples costs ${bag_cost}, then Brian would only be able to buy a maximum of ${money_left_for_apples}/${bag_cost} = {max_bags} bags of apples

If each bag of apples has a dozen ({apples_per_bag}) apples, then ({int(max_bags)}) two bags will have {apples_per_bag}*{int(max_bags)}= <<{int(max_bags)}*{apples_per_bag}={max_apples}>>{max_apples} apples
